skill.name: qutip
skill.description: Quantum mechanics simulations and analysis using QuTiP (Quantum Toolbox in Python). Use when working with quantum systems including: (1) quantum states (kets, bras, density matrices), (2) quantum operators and gates, (3) time evolution and dynamics (Schrödinger, master equations, Monte Carlo), (4) open quantum systems with dissipation, (5) quantum measurements and entanglement, (6) visualization (Bloch sphere, Wigner functions), (7) steady states and correlation functions, or (8) advanced methods (Floquet theory, HEOM, stochastic solvers). Handles both closed and open quantum systems across various domains including quantum optics, quantum computing, and condensed matter physics.

security_audit.summary: Reviewed six documentation files with no executable scripts. No data theft, network exfiltration, or malicious execution patterns were found.

content.value_statement: Quantum dynamics and open system modeling are complex and error prone. This skill guides QuTiP setup, solvers, analysis, and visualization with clear steps.
actual_capabilities: Define quantum states, density matrices, and operators using QuTiP Qobj utilities.
Run unitary and open system solvers such as sesolve, mesolve, and mcsolve.
Compute entropy, fidelity, concurrence, and correlation functions.
Visualize states with Bloch spheres, Wigner plots, and matrix histograms.
Apply advanced methods like Floquet solvers and HEOM setups.
limitations: Requires a Python environment with qutip installed.
Does not execute simulations or render plots; it provides guidance and code examples.
Does not access external data or quantum hardware.
Advanced methods assume user knowledge of model parameters and validity.

use_cases.title: Open system modeling
use_cases.description: Set up master equations with collapse operators and analyze steady states for dissipative quantum systems.

use_cases.title: Learning core solvers
use_cases.description: Practice sesolve, mesolve, and mcsolve workflows with clear, stepwise explanations.

use_cases.title: Qubit visualization
use_cases.description: Generate Bloch sphere and Wigner plots to interpret qubit and oscillator states.

prompt_templates.title: Basic two level system
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me QuTiP code to evolve a single qubit under sigma_z and plot expectation values.

prompt_templates.title: Open system with decay
prompt_templates.prompt: Guide me to model a damped harmonic oscillator with mesolve and collapse operators.

prompt_templates.title: Entanglement dynamics
prompt_templates.prompt: Provide steps to compute concurrence over time for two qubits with dephasing.

prompt_templates.title: Floquet and HEOM
prompt_templates.prompt: Outline a Floquet driven system and an HEOM setup, with key parameters to validate.

output_examples.input: Help me simulate a Jaynes-Cummings model and plot photon number over time.
output: Define cavity and atom operators with tensor products
Build the Hamiltonian and collapse operators
Run mesolve over a time list with e_ops for observables
Plot photon and atom populations versus time

best_practices: Start with small Hilbert space sizes and check convergence.
Choose the solver that matches state type and dissipation.
Use e_ops to store observables instead of full states.
anti_patterns: Using mesolve for pure unitary dynamics without collapse operators.
Ignoring solver tolerances or nsteps when results are unstable.
Requesting hardware execution or data downloads.

faq.question: What platforms does this skill support?
faq.answer: It provides guidance for QuTiP usage and works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code workflows.

faq.question: What are the main limits?
faq.answer: It does not run code or generate plots, and it depends on your local QuTiP installation.

faq.question: Can it integrate with my existing Python project?
faq.answer: Yes, it provides QuTiP snippets you can adapt and insert into your current codebase.

faq.question: Does it access my data or files?
faq.answer: No, it only provides instructions and does not read local files or credentials.

faq.question: What if I get solver errors or unstable results?
faq.answer: It suggests adjusting time steps, tolerances, and model definitions to stabilize results.

faq.question: How does it compare to general physics helpers?
faq.answer: It is focused on QuTiP APIs and workflows rather than broad theoretical explanations.
